title: The Year of Jubilee
shortSummary: Leviticus 25 outlines God's instructions to Israel regarding the Sabbath year and the Year of Jubilee, emphasizing rest for the land, economic justice, and the restoration of property and freedom. These laws reveal God's concern for holiness, social equity, and the acknowledgment that the land ultimately belongs to Him. The chapter teaches principles of trust in God's provision and care for the community.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period after the Exodus, during the giving of the Mosaic Law at Mount Sinai

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The mediator through whom God delivers the laws concerning the Sabbath year and Jubilee to the Israelites.

keyCharacters.name: Children of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The recipients of God's covenant laws, called to observe the Sabbath year and Jubilee as a sign of obedience and dependence on God.

definitions.definition: A seventh year during which the land is to rest and not be cultivated, symbolizing trust in God's provision and honoring His ownership of the land.
The fiftieth year following seven cycles of seven years, marked by the proclamation of liberty, release of debts, and restoration of property to original owners.
The act of buying back property or persons sold due to poverty, ensuring restoration and preventing permanent loss within the community.
Charging interest or increase on loans, which God forbids among His people to promote mercy and fairness.

outline.heading: The Sabbath Year for the Land
outline.description: God commands Israel to let the land rest every seventh year, forbidding sowing and harvesting of crops, so the land itself observes a Sabbath, providing food for all living creatures and teaching reliance on God's provision.

outline.heading: The Year of Jubilee Declared
outline.description: After seven cycles of seven years, the fiftieth year is proclaimed as a Jubilee year, a holy time of liberty when all property is returned to original owners and families are restored, symbolizing God's ultimate ownership and mercy.

outline.heading: Regulations on Buying, Selling, and Redemption
outline.description: Instructions are given to ensure fairness in land transactions, with prices adjusted according to the years remaining until the Jubilee, and provisions for redeeming sold land to prevent permanent loss of inheritance.

outline.heading: Special Rules for Houses and Levite Property
outline.description: Specific laws distinguish between houses in walled cities and villages, and the perpetual possession of Levite properties, highlighting the sacredness of certain inheritances and the importance of community stability.

outline.heading: Care for the Poor and Servants
outline.description: God commands mercy toward impoverished brethren, forbidding exploitation through interest or harsh treatment, and sets rules for Hebrew servants, emphasizing their eventual freedom at Jubilee and reminding Israel of their identity as God's servants.

application: Trust God’s provision by resting from anxious labor and honoring His commands to rest and trust in His timing.
Practice generosity and fairness in financial dealings, avoiding exploitation of others, especially those in need.
Remember that all we have ultimately belongs to God, encouraging us to steward resources with humility and care.
Show mercy and compassion to those who are struggling, reflecting God’s heart for justice and restoration.

keyVerses.text: And ye shall hallow the fiftieth year, and proclaim liberty throughout all the land unto all the inhabitants thereof: it shall be a jubile unto you; and ye shall return every man unto his possession, and ye shall return every man unto his family.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the Jubilee as a divine institution of freedom and restoration, underscoring God's justice and mercy.

keyVerses.text: The land shall not be sold for ever: for the land is mine; for ye are strangers and sojourners with me.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reminds Israel that God is the true owner of the land, teaching humility and stewardship.

keyVerses.text: I am the LORD your God, which brought you forth out of the land of Egypt, to give you the land of Canaan, and to be your God.
keyVerses.significance: God asserts His authority and covenant relationship, grounding the laws in His redemptive work and ongoing care.

keyVerses.text: For unto me the children of Israel are servants; they are my servants whom I brought forth out of the land of Egypt: I am the LORD your God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes Israel’s identity as God’s servants, reinforcing the call to obedience and reverence.
